text: If I were to roll out Ubuntu in a network environment with a Windows server, is there a way to make Ubuntu 'read' LDAP so users can log in with domain accounts?
sure, but it is a read only connection, not read/write for password updates
you need an ldap proxy or a service such as redhats directory service to do updates
I'm not sure I understand what you just said there...
what updates?
to users passwords for example
I'm not following what you're referring to in regard to user password updates. What gets updated? What needs updated?
when a user changes their password it is updated in the ldap schema, if you are using AD only windows machines can update it, the Linux ones can auth against it, but not update it
are you talking in reference to when passwords expire?
no, just any reason for a user to change their password, eg: they just want to
oh, we're in a school district here. We don't allow users to just change passwords, however we force automatic password changes every 90 days.
excluding students.
all teachers/staff get the auto change.
ok, so they would have to change that from a windows machine, or you'd have to have a linux ldap-> windows AD proxy
so it COULD work - they just wouldnt auto-change the passwords when prompted through ubuntu.
however, we're talking ubuntu for students, so they would never see password changes on the ubuntu systems.
sounds fine

my main concern is in windows, we auto-redirect their my documents to be the \\server\student\john_smith. I'm wondering if there's a way to re-direct their home folder, or at least a folder on the desktop to do the same thing.
do you by chance know if thats a possibility?
yes, that should be do-able, the AD-ldap schema is quite configurable
you set the PS1 variable to what ever you want the prompt to be
need what changed
I ran a gvfs-mount command in terminal, and now it changed my prompt to a simple $
ok, why is the prompt being $ a problem
because this may be a production machine, and I do not want $ as the prompt.
the prompt being $ is not an issue, it doesn't change anything
I would like my prompt changed to default. Do you know how? If not I will ask somebody else.
use the PS1 varible to change the prompt to whatever you want
however, again it makes no difference to the machines use
PS1?
yes, the PS1 environment variable
I apologize, I have no idea what that means.
it's just an environment variable, like PATH for example
I see. not sure if I'm following... how do I flip it back?
I'm not sure why doing a mount command has changed it, also look at peep`'s suggestion, that is a simpler way
okay. So I need to set the PS1 variable. How do I go about that?
it's an environment variable, same as any other, peep`'s suggestion is easier though
peep didn't have a suggestion. he just made a comment.
you need to not use network manager as that won't make a connection until you login and activate it
he made an excellent suggestion, re-read it
according to google, that is incorrect, as 'allow for all users' supposedly allows that SSID to connect with network manager prior to logging in.
I think I may have just been impatient, as I was able to log in just now. Rebooting and I'll wait 30 seconds to see if it'll pick up the wifi
it won't though
it will need to bond
how do you know it wont. I think it just worked for me.
it takes time
they keys have to be saved though,
bingo.
it worked just now.
if you do it outside of network manager it will be a lot quicker
outside of network manager? as in using what instead?
using the interfaces file
for wireless?
that stores the passwords in plain text though, doesnt it.
what directory are you in when you run it
I have no idea, as I'm at the.... $ prompt....
type 'pwd' to know what directory you are in
what directory are you in ?
my home directory. Mind you this is a domain account too
it should be in your home dir then
it's up to you what you do
if you don't want to deploy it because the prompt isn't what you want and you don't know how to set the prompt to what you want, don't deploy it
that's not the point.
it is
I want ubuntu to act predictably and sensibly if I'm going to manage it.
retarded issues like this make me think twice unless I know a work around.
SO, I'm going to find a work around. I'm sorry you have a problem with that, but you are not managing these systems.
if you are unable to set an environment varible, you should not be in a position to make deployment decisions or in a position where you admin a server
show me the output of 'id' in your terminal
well then explain to me what I am doing wrong? After all, I'm using your suggestions that are not working.
appreciate it if you don't insult me, by the way.
you've not set the PS1 environment variable, that is the problem, however it should be sourced from your home directory, however it's not so there is th bug
I have a lot of experience in mass deployment of systems, as I have 2,000 to manage.
I'm not insulting you, I'm stating fact

also keep in mind we dont run linux here.
it's up to you how you take it

and this is my job, to figure it out and deploy it accordingly.
ok, so show me the output of 'id'
it's a long, long string.
ok, paste it
if you want help, you need to cut the attitude out a little
keep the smart comments at bay, and we'll have no issues. thank you.
tell you what, help yourself, I'm out

I'm not interested
just wanted to make you aware that it clearly has nothing to do with bashrc after all.
you know, in case anyone else asks. ;)
not interested
just trying to be pro active in case anybody else has the same issue.
that's all :)
I didn't think it was local to the machine, more so as your directory is network mounted at a domain level,
yar. I'm just not sure what's sticking it. AD has nothing that stands out as being weird, and nothing is in my share on the server either.
I am.
can you paste your configs for both in a pastebin please.

ok, this is common in RHEL and I'd assume it's the same here, you need an entry for both your other NIC's confirming they are nothing, eg: so they are 'blanked' before going into the bond
also check out and make sure nothing like network manager has a grip on one of them also
do I need a 2nd entry with bond0:0 for the 2nd card? I thought they'd both point (etho and eth1) to the same bond.
there is no network manager.
bond0:0 is a virtual interface on the bond, so no, you shouldn't need that
however an entry for eth0 and eth1 to 'null' them may help
hm, then I'm completely lost. EVERY guide I've read has said to do what I did here, with 1 or 2 mentioning bond0:0
you understand what :1 or:0 after a network card does in general yes/no ?
my goal is to have both NICs on the same IP to boost speed for our thin client lab.
I knew it was a virtual interface. I just wasn't sure if that was needed for bonding.
the guides I read mentioning bond0:0 also had a separate IP for the virtual interface, which I don't really want. I'd like to have 1 IP for both NICs to handle the load.
ok cool, so you're not starting from scratch, bond0 is your virtual nic, so that's what has the IP's you want to add eth0 and eth1 so no need to reference bond0:0
you also need a mii-mode so the cards no if it's round robin, load balanced mode etc
well I did create a file somewhere with a miimode entry... downdelay updelay etc...
I forget where it was tho. let me see if I can find that guide. It was /etc/modprobe.d or something
great, that's an important bit
ifenslave.conf

heres the contents of the ifenslave.conf alias bond0 bonding
https://help.ubuntu.com/community/UbuntuBonding
that is a great way of doing it, simple and obvious,
wait, I still need an auto eth0 entry?
auto eth0 and auto bond0
no, look at the example
that's where I read it.
under 10.04 and newer.
eth1 and eth2 are in the bond, eth0 is just a nic
so I need miimon in the interface file under the bond listing?
that exmaple has 3 nics, eth0 just on it's own and a bond with eth1 and 2 in it in load balancing mode
oh I see.
I took that the wrong way.
I'll be honest, I'm not really understanding where I went wrong then.
that's just an example of a guys box, not copy this file for a bonding cvonfig, you'll need to apply that config to your config
right. I'd just have to plug my numbers in.
correct, and remove what you don't need, eth0 doing dhcp
oh, I see bond-slaves there. I didnt have that before.
it'd be nice if these fricken guides said to do some of this stuff.
because you are doing the adding as a slave option, which from my experience is poor
always use official ubuntu guides, they do tell you the right way of doing things
the way you seem to be trying to do it is quite dirty in my opinion
wait, what I'm doing is a poor idea?
no no, bonding is great, no complaint, I mean how you are implementing bonding
well, what's the best way of doing it?
the guide I've just given you
make sure you read it all though, so you understand the modes etc
oh. But it mentions bond-slave in the interface file that you just gave me. Then you mentioned slave is poor, so I got confused.
no, I mentioned the way you are adding a slave in your example is poor
if you are doing a bond you need slaves
do you think the bond-slaves entry alone is why eth1 didnt attach to bond0?
well I copied that config exactly, now I have 0 connectivity. :(
it's not just copying that config, did you read the whole thing as I suggested ?

well, really just the basics of the entire method behind this. Like if I run ssh-keygen, am I doing this on my file server, or the client system outside of the LAN?

really simple, ssh-keygen (man it - and chose your options) public key put in the ~/.ssh/authorized_keys file on the server - private key, keep on your local machine, ssh $user@$server, enter private key password, you are done
make sure the ~/.ssh/authorized_key file on the server has 600 permissions
I was under the impression I was to copy the public key physically off of that system and onto the client system outside of the LAN.
correct, public key onto the destination server, in the .ssh directory in their home file, and put the contents into a file called 'authorized keys'
authorized_keys sorry, hit spoace by accident
just to recap... ssh-keygen on server, find the public key, copy it to the client. Then the client should be able to SSH in without asking for a pw. correct?
ssh keygen on client,
that creates public and private keys
see, I did that, and Ithought I did it wrong. I found it so backwards to do it from the client and successfully SSH into it with ZERO server input. It confused me....
private key in your .ssh directory (call the file id_dsa or or_rsa depending on encyrption)
put the contents (not the file - the contents) into a file called 'authorized_keys' on the server, in the users home directory/.ssh
change the permissions of the authorized_key file to 600 on the server, bang you are done

so in essence I was looking at it 100% backwards. I generate the keys on client, and move the private key contents to server.... whereas I thought I would keygen on server, and move public to client....
public key contents tot he server
private key stays safe on the client
want to do this step by step ?
eh, I'm trying it out on my own, but I'm still very gray about it. Hate to be a bug though.
youtube videos weren't as explicit as I had hoped :(
want to walk through this - it will take 5 minutes max, it's really easy
if you wouldn't mind...
lets do the client first, got a terminal open ?
sure do
ok, 'ssh-keygen -b 2048 '
that should create two files, a public and a private key in your current working directory
just enter/enter/enter thruogh the prompts?
yeah, set a password though
you want your key to be passworded
the prompts are pretty self explanintory, so if you want to change something to match your needs, please do so
now that the keygen is made, what should my plan of action be?
ok, you have a public and a private key, yes no ?
would it be in .ssh?
should be in your current working directory (unless you told it to put it somewhere else)
I'm not seeing anything besides typical home dir folders.
did it ask you for output file names ?
besides pw, I just enter'd everything else
look in .ssh
~/.ssh
you sould have id_rsa and id_rsa.pub
great, your id_rsa is your private key, guard it with your life
your .public key, copy that onto your remote server, to the ~/.ssh directory
that's where I copy the contents, but not the entire .pub itself, right?
as this is the first key, we'll copy the whole file (you'll see why, it will make sense in a moment)
copy the physical file (.pub) to ~/.ssh on the remote server
you following ok ?
yeah, just trying to push the pub over to server.
the hdd I have shared on my router is being a brat.
that's fine, just checking your ok
maybe it was nautilus. gnome 3 just crashed and reset on my laptop. haaa??
copied over. are we done??
very close
now, change the file name on the remote server from 'id_rsa.pub' to 'authorized_keys'
done
normally the plan is to copy the contents of id_rsa.pub to the file authorized_keys, but as this is your only / first key, it's easier to just rename it
change the permissions on it to 600
change permissions on authorized_keys to 600
can I throw out a curve ball first?
please
no problem

there will be a total of 4 systems connecting to this server via ssh. Each user will be backing their files up to it with an automated program, etiher syncback or deja dup depending on windows or ubuntu. Now, I see the ssh key is kept in ~/.ssh... how would this effect other users?
are all the users using the same username ?
no.
then no,
that will cause no added complication
either way, you're done, just ssh in now from the client
what about the fact that the ssh keys are stored in the users home directory?
why is it bad that the keys are stored in the users home directory
should ask you for your key password

I don't consider it bad. I just want to make sure it'll work. Like, I now have a file on the admin account of my file server called authorized_keys. that's just 1 key. What about when I add 3 more? do I just add them in the same file?
no, each user has their own authorized_keys file in their home directory
if you want others to share the same username, but with different keys, then you just add more public keys to the single authorized_keys file
separated by anything in aprticular?
nope, no spaces, end of line, start a new line
good deal

so I don't assign these keys as per user individually. I could just generate 4 keys and just make sure I drop 1 private key per user and they'll be associated accordingly,r ight? I mean there's no marriage between sshkey1 and Frank, or sshkey2 and Bob, it's just sshkey1pub - sshkey1priv, right?
yup, look at the ssh keygen options, eg: -c (comment) is useful to show users keys eg: -c 'Roasteds key' - helps in a file with multiple keys
I see. so I could just barf out 4 keys, stack them in authorized keys, and freely distribute the private keys to each user and bam - good togo. eh?
for example here is my key
http://pastebin.ubuntu.com/850269/
if you look at the end, it has my name, which in a file with many keys, shows it is obviously mine, so if I need to remove it, I know which one to remove
but, yes, it's that simple
get it ?
I'm not sure if I did this right. I just tried to SSH to it from client and it said authenticity of host can't be established. are you sure you want to continue connecting.
first connection, just cliek yes
oh, I thought it wouldnt ask for anything at all
you need to disable host based auth in sshd_config to stop that
or put the hosts in the ~/.ssh/known_hosts file, whatever works best for you
it's fine, I just thought using priv pub sshkeys I wouldn't get ANY prompts.
it will only ask that one
it just confused me is all.
you won't get any prompts if you set it up correctly, eg: disable host based auth, OR put the host keys in the known_hosts file
had my sshkeys not been working properly, it would have generated a new ssh key in .ssh, correct?
no
no new keys
you are now 'setup'
when you connected it will add a host key to ~/.ssh/known_hosts
but if I hadn't set these keys up, and ssh'd anyway, it would have generated one on the fly, right?
god no
that would be an amazingly large security hole
so how does ssh work if I don't set up ssh keys? I never did it before and I could ssh just fine (but that was on the LAN)
it just wouldn't have let you login with key based auth
that is user/password authentication
ah, different beast?
if you disable user/password authentication and don't have an ssh key it won't let you login
where's that done at out of curiosity?
password authentication hits /etc/passwd -> /etc/shadow on the server, for auth, ssh keys uses the keys you created for auth and ignores /etc/passwd
I see.
so I just have to repeat this process 3 more times and I should be good?
pretty much
nice. thanks for your help.
it's appreciated.
you may want to improve it, eg: add comments to the key, disable host based auth, etc etc
but at a highlevel, yes, it's that simple
# comments?
yes, -c 'jimmys key' so it's obvious who owns what key in the authorized_keys file
do these keys ever have to be refreshed?
can I expect to redo this next month or something?
nope
I've had the same key for 12 years
lol
impressive.
it's a very effective method
its simple when you think about it...
eg: you want to give me access to your machine, I give you my public key, bang we are done
ssh-keygen, type pw, it barfs out 2 files, .pub contents to server in authorized_keys
you want me to not have access, you remove it, bang your done
we don't have to know passwords etc etc
correct
very nice.
thanks for the help. I'm gonna get to creating these quick.
just to recap, client is ALWAYS private, right?
guard it with your life
see, that makes no sense to me. I would think server would be private...
no, you are the user who moves around, this is your data
you take the private key with you
however, even if someone steals mom's laptop, I can just nuke her public key on the server and all is well
not to mention, her user doesn't have root access, so itd be limited, albeit still bad
correct
plus if you password the private key, it's pretty much worthless too
sounds good.
eg: if someone steals my private key, they can't use it unless they know the password, they can try to brute force it, but they will be trying for 128years
a good way to invest precious time
take 2 minutes to setup, lasts 8 years and counting
unless you by cahnce know how to incorporate the private key into a windows box :/

sure

sure, but it is a read only connection, not read/write for password updates
you need an ldap proxy or a service such as redhats directory service to do updates

to users passwords for example
I'm not following what you're referring to in regard to user password updates. What gets updated? What needs updated?
when a user changes their password it is updated in the ldap schema, if you are using AD only windows machines can update it, the Linux ones can auth against it, but not update it

well, really just the basics of the entire method behind this. Like if I run ssh-keygen, am I doing this on my file server, or the client system outside of the LAN?

really simple, ssh-keygen (man it - and chose your options) public key put in the ~/.ssh/authorized_keys file on the server - private key, keep on your local machine, ssh $user@$server, enter private key password, you are done
make sure the ~/.ssh/authorized_key file on the server has 600 permissions
I was under the impression I was to copy the public key physically off of that system and onto the client system outside of the LAN.
correct, public key onto the destination server, in the .ssh directory in their home file, and put the contents into a file called 'authorized keys'
authorized_keys sorry, hit spoace by accident
just to recap... ssh-keygen on server, find the public key, copy it to the client. Then the client should be able to SSH in without asking for a pw. correct?
ssh keygen on client,
that creates public and private keys
see, I did that, and Ithought I did it wrong. I found it so backwards to do it from the client and successfully SSH into it with ZERO server input. It confused me....
private key in your .ssh directory (call the file id_dsa or or_rsa depending on encyrption)
put the contents (not the file - the contents) into a file called 'authorized_keys' on the server, in the users home directory/.ssh
change the permissions of the authorized_key file to 600 on the server, bang you are done

so in essence I was looking at it 100% backwards. I generate the keys on client, and move the private key contents to server.... whereas I thought I would keygen on server, and move public to client....
public key contents tot he server
private key stays safe on the client
